questions.question: What kind of wound is an open cardiac massage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Contaminated Explanation: Open cardiac massage is classified as Category 3 due to a significant breach in sterile technique. It is generally performed in situations of inadequate cardiac output, following emergency thoracotomy for penetrating chest trauma, during pericardial tamponade, or in cases of cardiac arrest after recent chest surgery. Classification of Wounds: Classification Description Class I Clean An uninfected operative wound with no inflammation and no entry into the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts. Wounds are primarily closed, and drainage is closed if needed. Class II Clean-Contaminated An operative wound where the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Includes operations like biliary tract, appendix, vagina, and oropharynx. Class III Contaminated Open, fresh accidental wounds or operations with major breaks in sterile technique (open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract , with acute non-purulent inflammation. Class IV Dirty-Infected Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue, clinical infection, or perforated viscera. The organisms causing postoperative infection were already present in the operative field before the operation. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 225

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, bluish nodules on the skin with no infections are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lymphangiosarcoma Explanation: Lymphangiosarcoma is the most likely cause of these symptoms, especially in a patient with a history of mastectomy. This condition, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome , can develop years after mastectomy due to long-standing lymphedema, which is a consequence of lymphatic obstruction. Complications of mastectomy: Complications Explanations Lymphedema Swelling is caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm or chest wall due to the removal of lymph nodes.(After MRM and axillary dissection) Wound infection/Flap necrosis Postoperative infections where blackening of suture line is seen (flap necrosis), if necrosed site note removed, leads to wound infection Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome Chronic pain in the chest or upper arm due to nerve damage or scar tissue formation. Nerve Injuries Long thoracic nerve- injury leads to winging of the scapula Thoracodorsal nerve Lymphangiosarcoma Stewart-Treves syndrome - Cancerous growth in the lymphatic vessels, often associated with long-standing lymphedema. After an average of 10.5 years following MRM and radiotherapy, the patient develops angiosarcoma Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Option B) is characterised by symptoms such as pain, paraesthesia, oedema, cyanosis, cold extremities, and weakness in the hands. Chronic Venous Insufficiency (Option C) typically presents with postural discomfort, varicose veins, oedema, skin pigmentation, induration, dermatitis, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulceration. Recurrent Breast Cancer (Option D) usually presents with a palpable lump, nipple retraction, swelling of lymph nodes, and signs of metastasis. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 832. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 25, 26. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538212/#:~:text=Patients%20tolerate%20mastectomy%20well%20in, breakdown%20or%20necrosis,%20and%20lymphedema .

questions.question: A patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with shock and hypotension. The extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative, the X-ray is normal, and the ECG shows no abnormalities. The patient's SpO2 is 93%, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and pulse rate is 40/min. Based on this information, what type of shock is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Neurogenic shock Explanation: Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension, bradycardia (low pulse rate), and normal or slightly reduced SpO2. The absence of trauma to solid organs, negative eFAST, and normal X-rays help rule out hemorrhagic or cardiogenic shock. The bradycardia (pulse of 40/min) is due to a loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injury or severe trauma, leading to vasodilation and bradycardia. Neurogenic shock: In neurogenic shock, there is a loss of sympathetic tone, leading to vasodilation of the peripheral vasculature, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance and hypotension. This is the primary mechanism underlying neurogenic shock. Causes: Neurogenic shock is a critical condition that results from the dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system following spinal cord injury, especially in the cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae above the T6 level, as a result of traumatic events. The dysregulation arises due to the lack of sympathetic tone and decreased peripheral vascular resistance. The decline in sympathetic tone prompts the dilation of capacitance blood vessels in the lower extremities. This, in turn, results in decreased cardiac filling, leading to hypotension and shock. Reduced sympathetic control over the heart leads to a situation where unopposed vagal cardiac influence causes bradycardia. Patients with neurogenic shock may also exhibit pink and warm skin due to the dilation of subcutaneous blood vessels. Severe brain injury. Certain anaesthetics. Pathophysiology Clinical Manifestations: Hypotension Bradycardia (unlike other forms of shock) Warm, dry skin below injury level Priapism in males Respiratory compromise (if high cervical injury) Poikilothermia (inability to regulate body temperature) Physiological Hemodynamic Characteristics of Shock Type of Shock Cardiac Output Systemic Vascular Resistance Central Venous Pressure Mean Arterial Pressure Hypovolemic ↓ ↑ ↓ ↓ Cardiogenic ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓ Distributive(Septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic) ↑ or ↓ ↓ ↓ or N ↓ Obstructive (pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax) ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓

questions.question: In patients at risk of refeeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hyperkalemia Explanation: Hyperkalemia is not typically associated with refeeding syndrome. In fact, potassium levels usually decrease during refeeding, contributing to hypokalemia. Refeeding syndrome: One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding. This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER. One or more of the following: (OR) Two or more of the following: BMI <16 kg/m 2 BMI <18.5 kg/m 2 Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months. Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days. Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics. Mechanism of Refeeding Syndrome: Electrolyte abnormalities: Hypophosphatemia (Option D) Hypomagnesemia Hypokalemia (Option A) Hypocalcemia (Option C) This leads to arrhythmia, confusion, and respiratory failure, ultimately leading to death. Management: Matching the intake with requirements. Avoid overfeeding Calorie delivery should be increased slowly Vitamin administration (Thiamine): Given before feeding. Electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 340

questions.question: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the image:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rolled out Explanation: The given image shows rolled-out edges suggesting Basal cell carcinoma. Morphologically, an ulcer has 4 parts: Base: Surface on which ulcer rests ( usually underlying muscles/bones ) Floor: Exposed surface of ulcer (usually seen as purulent discharge/granulation tissue/red and moist ) Margin: Junction between normal epithelium & ulcer Edge: Area between margin & floor Type of edges Clinical conditions Details Sloping edge Healing ulcer Varicose ulcer Inner part: Red (healthy granulation tissue) Middle part: Blue (epithelial proliferation) Outer part: White (scar/fibrous tissue) Undermined edge Tubercular ulcers Disease process advances in the deeper plane (subcutaneous tissue), whereas (skin) epidermis proliferates inwards Punched out edge Arterial / Ischemic ulcers Gummatous (syphilitic) ulcer Trophic ulcer Due to endarteritis Raised & beaded edge Rolled out / Pearly white edge Rodent ulcer- Basal cell carcinoma Beads are due to proliferating active cells Pearly white in appearance Everted edge / Rolled out edge Squamous cell carcinoma Due to the spill of proliferating malignant tissue over the normal skin

questions.question: A patient following a road traffic accident (RTA) with a crush injury presents with crepitus and a reddish-brown wound within 3 days after amputation. What is the most likely condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gas gangrene Explanation: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium species, typically after traumatic injuries, especially with crush wounds or amputation. It is characterized by crepitus (gas production), reddish-brown discoloration of the wound, and rapid progression within days. Gas Gangrene A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries. Cause Clostridium perfringens Incubation period <24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks Sources and predisposing factors Contaminated soil and feces. Wounds with necrotic or foreign material. Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations. Anaerobic environments in the wound. Common sites of infection Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks. Subscapular region in the upper limb. Clinical features Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity. Serosanguineous discharge. Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae. Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus. Complication Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure. Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections. Death occurs in critically ill patients. Investigation X-ray: Gas in soft tissues. Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils. Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure. Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis. CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds. Treatment High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously. Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously. All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds. Amputation done in severe cases Hyperbaric oxygen therapy. Prevention Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds. Devitalized wounds should not be sutured. Adequate cleaning of wounds with H I O I and normal saline. Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic. Image Incorrect Options: Impetigo (Option B) is a superficial skin infection caused by Streptococcus or Staphylococcus bacteria, presenting as honey-colored crusts, but does not typically cause crepitus or involve deep tissue. Tetanus (Option C) results from infection with Clostridium tetani , leading to muscle stiffness and spasms. While it follows a traumatic injury, it doesn’t typically present with crepitus or reddish-brown wound discoloration. Cellulitis (Option D) is a bacterial skin infection that causes redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not produce crepitus or reddish-brown wounds and typically develops over a longer period.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling Explanation: Wound healing occurs in four stages : hemostasis , inflammation , proliferation , and remodeling . Hemostasis: Occurs immediately after injury: vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and clot formation. Platelets release growth factors (e.g., TGF- β , PDGF , VEGF ) that promote matrix deposition, chemotaxis, and angiogenesis. Coagulation cascade leads to thrombin formation, stabilizing the platelet plug. Inflammation: Early Phase (Days 1-2): Neutrophils clear debris and fight infection. Vasoactive amines increase vascular permeability. Late Phase (Days 2-3): Macrophages debride the wound, release growth factors, and promote fibroblast and angiogenesis. Cardinal signs: rubor (redness), tumor (swelling), calor (heat), dolor (pain). Proliferation: Days 3-14: Fibroblasts produce collagen and extracellular matrix. Granulation tissue forms, and angiogenesis occurs. Myofibroblasts help contract the wound and bring edges together. Remodelling: Weeks to months: Type III collagen is replaced by stronger type I collagen . The wound reaches about 80% of normal skin strength by 12 weeks and continues to mature for up to a year. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 25,26

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient?

options.D: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound Explanation: Serosanguinous drainage from the wound is considered a "sure sign" of abdominal wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient (Salmon fluid sign) Wound dehiscence is the disruption of any or all layers of a wound. It occurs in up to 3% of abdominal wounds and is associated with an increased risk of postoperative mortality. Timing and Presentation: Wound dehiscence typically occurs 5 to 8 days postoperatively when the strength of the wound is at its weakest. It often presents with serosanguinous discharge and may be preceded by a popping sensation felt by the patient, particularly during activities like straining or coughing. The dehiscence may also indicate an underlying abscess. Risk factors: Poor wound closure or closure under tension Infection , hematoma , or seroma at the wound site Increased intra-abdominal pressure , e.g., in postoperative patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or excessive coughing Malnourishment Diabetes Obesity Renal failure Jaundice Sepsis Cancer Steroid use Emergency surgery Management: Full-thickness dehiscence generally requires the patient to return to the operating room for resuturing. In cases of infected tissues, poor-quality tissue, or wounds under excessive tension, the wound may be left open and managed with dressings or vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) . Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 325

questions.question: An elderly chronic smoker male is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip with no lymph node involvement. What is the treatment of choice?

options.C: Wide local excision with negative borders
options.D: Wide local excision with frozen section

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Wide local excision with negative borders Explanation: Wide local excision with frozen section is the treatment of choice for early-stage squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip in patients with no lymph node involvement. This technique ensures that the excision margins are clear in real-time, reducing the risk of recurrence. Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinising cells in the epidermis, commonly arising from the stratum basalis. It is the second most common skin cancer, more prevalent in fair-skinned individuals with chronic sun exposure. Risk factors: UV radiation , chronic inflammation, immunosuppression , chemical carcinogens (e.g., arsenic), and HPV infection (types 5 and 16). Tobacco use doubles the risk. Precursor lesions: Actinic Keratosis (AK) : Dysplastic lesions from sun damage; 20% progress to SCC. Keratin Horns : Raised keratinous surface from AK, 10% may have underlying SCC. Keratoacanthomas : Rapidly growing, nodular tumors that resemble SCC and should be excised. Clinical features: SCC presents as nodular, verrucous, or ulcerating lesions with an everted edge and surrounding induration. Differential diagnosis : AK, BCC, pyoderma gangrenosum, and warts. Microscopic features: Irregular squamous epithelium invading the dermis, positive for cytokeratins 1 and 10 . Broders' grading assesses tumor differentiation. Management: The primary treatment for SCC is surgical excision , which provides accurate histological diagnosis and clear margins . The size of the SCC influences the required margin: <2 cm SCC : 4 mm margin >2 cm SCC : 1 cm margin The recurrence rate is approximately 20% . Surgical excision is the only reliable method for ensuring clear margins. Mohs’ micrographic surgery may be indicated for difficult-to-resect tumours or those with recurrent SCC. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 652-655

questions.question: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Red Explanation: In triage, the Red category represents patients who have life-threatening injuries or conditions but can survive with immediate medical intervention. These patients are prioritised for treatment and intervention to prevent imminent death. Triage colour coding systems: Colour Priority Medical Need Clinical Status Examples Red First Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early Severe facial trauma Tension pneumothorax Profuse external bleeding Haemothorax Flail chest Major intra-abdominal bleed Extradural haematomas Yellow (Option B) Second Urgent Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given within hours Compound fractures Degloving injuries Ruptured abdominal viscus Pelvic fracture Spinal injuries Green (Option C) Third Non-Urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days Simple fractures Sprains Minor lacerations Black (Option D) Last Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help. Severe brain damage Very extensive burns Major disruption/ loss of chest or abdominal wall structures Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 449 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 560, 561 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557583/

questions.question: What type of skin graft is used in the image shown?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Split thickness Explanation: The image in question depicts a split-thickness skin graft (STSG), which consists of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. These grafts are typically harvested from areas such as the inner thigh. Due to their ease of harvesting and ability to cover larger wounds, split-thickness grafts are commonly used for extensive skin coverage. Feature Thiersch Graft (Split-Thickness Skin Graft) Wolfe Graft (Full-Thickness Skin Graft) Type of Skin Grafting Split-thickness Full-thickness Composition Epidermis + part of dermis Epidermis + full thickness of dermis Graft Size Large grafts can be taken Only small grafts can be taken Graft Survival Easier More difficult Donor Site Healing Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts Graft Contraction Significant contraction, leading to poor cosmetic appearance Lesser contraction, better cosmetic appearance Common Donor Sites Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin Donor Site Exclusions None Axilla is not used as a donor site Advantages of Harvesting Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.question: A female patient presents to the outpatient department 10 days postpartum with complaints of a fluctuant breast mass with tenderness, high-grade fever, and cracked nipples. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Breast abscess Explanation: A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, most commonly seen in lactating women. The patient's clinical presentation, including a fluctuant mass, high fever, and localized tenderness, strongly suggests this diagnosis. Breast Abscess Definition Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue. Types Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding. Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis. Causes and Risk Factors Lactation: Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers. Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings). Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts. Non-Lactation: Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation. Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis. Smoking and diabetes as risk factors. Signs and symptoms Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes Diagnosis Ultrasonography: Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis. Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation. Treatment Lactational Mastitis: Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin). Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping. Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia. Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision. Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification. Non-Lactational Mastitis: Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections. Needle aspiration for abscess drainage. Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula. Incorrect Options: Breast engorgement (Option A) is not associated with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain. Acute mastitis (Option C) can cause breast pain and swelling, but it typically does not present as a fluctuant mass. Fibroadenoma (Option D) does not present with a fluctuant mass, high fever, or localized pain. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 927, 928 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 826, 827 Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Pages 550-553, 601, 602

questions.question: A 55-year-old female patient with chronic pancreatitis undergoes a Puestow procedure. What is the most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) Explanation: TPN is typically indicated when enteral feeding via the gastrointestinal tract is not possible or not well tolerated. After a Puestow procedure , especially if there are concerns about pancreatic insufficiency, altered gut anatomy, or complications like fistulas. Post-operative care in patients with chronic pancreatitis following a Puestow procedure: Nutrition : Provide nutrition via TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) or jejunostomy feeding , depending on the patient's condition and tolerance. Fluid and electrolyte management : Ensure careful monitoring and correction of fluid and electrolyte balance. Sepsis prevention and control : Take proactive measures to prevent infections and monitor for signs of sepsis regularly. Octreotide use : Administer octreotide during the surgery and continue at regular intervals or as a slow infusion postoperatively for up to 5 days to help reduce pancreatic secretion and minimize complications. TPN Formulations: 3 in 1 formulation 2 in 1 formulation Solutions with lipids (Option C) Solutions without lipids 60/20/20 60% by dextrose 20% by amino acids 20% by fat. 75/25 75% by dextrose 25% by amino acids No lipids used Fiber is absent in both formulations Complications of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN): Line Insertion Complications Pneumothorax (most dangerous) Misplacement of catheter Line-Related Complications Sepsis (most common) Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use) Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome) Metabolic Complications Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia) Liver dysfunction Metabolic bone disease Vitamin deficiencies Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 693. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 338, 339.

questions.question: Identify the incision made and marked in the image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gibson Abernathy Explanation: The given image shows Gibson Abernathy's incision. Gibson Abernathy incision: Primary Use: Provides access to the lower/distal part of the ureter. Procedure Steps: The patient is placed in a supine position. The incision is made 1 inch medial to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), extending 1 inch above the inguinal ligament toward the pubic symphysis. Indications: Renal transplant offers less trauma and convenient access to the iliac fossa and bladder. Laparoscopic surgery is used as access for the non-dominant hand. Open nephroureterectomy, facilitates splitting the rectus fascia and developing the space of Retzius for distal ureterectomy. Kidney excision and removal of the renal specimen from the entrapment sac. Incision Type Description Common Uses Abdominal Incisions Midline Longitudinal cut through the linea alba, bloodless access Exploratory laparotomy, trauma surgery, emergency surgeries Periumbilical Incisions around the umbilicus, avoiding the umbilical stalk Laparoscopy, umbilical hernia repairs, postpartum tubal ligation Pararectus Along the semilunar line, lateral to the rectus abdominis Abdominal wall hernia repairs,

questions.question: Identify the test provided in the image below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Allen’s test Explanation: The given image shows Allen’s test. Allen's Test is a clinical manoeuvre used to assess the blood flow to the hand, specifically evaluating the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries. It is commonly used before procedures like inserting an arterial line or taking a blood sample from the radial artery. Procedure: The patient is asked to make a fist, compressing the radial and ulnar arteries simultaneously. The patient is then asked to open their hand (which should appear pale). Once the hand is open, the examiner releases one of the arteries (usually the ulnar artery). The test is positive if normal colour returns to the hand quickly (within 5-10 seconds), indicating adequate collateral circulation. If there is a delay in the colour return or no return, this may suggest compromised blood flow through the released artery, which could indicate arterial occlusion & the radial artery should not be pricked. Adson's test (Option B) is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which occurs due to compression of the brachial plexus or subclavian artery in the thoracic outlet. The patient is instructed to extend their neck and turn their head toward the arm being tested while the examiner palpates the radial pulse. The patient then takes a deep breath. A positive test is indicated by a reduction or disappearance of the radial pulse, suggesting compression in the thoracic outlet. Elevated Arm Stress Test (Option C) evaluates thoracic outlet syndrome by assessing the compression of neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet. The patient’s arms are raised above the head and held for 1-2 minutes. A positive test occurs if the patient experiences symptoms of numbness, tingling, or a decrease in the radial pulse, which indicates compression of the neurovascular bundle in the thoracic outlet. Nicoladoni's test (Option D) is used to assess for increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or brainstem compression . The test is positive if the patient exhibits a sudden drop in pulse or blood pressure when their head is tilted backwards (in a hyperextended position).

questions.question: Smoking increases the risk of which of the following diseases? Duct ectasia Fibroadenoma Mondor disease Breast carcinoma
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1, 3, 4 Explanation: Smoking is not directly associated with an increased risk of fibroadenomas, which are benign breast tumours often occurring in younger women. Smoking increases the risk of duct ectasia , Mondor disease , and breast carcinoma , but not fibroadenoma . Duct ectasia refers to the dilation or enlargement of the milk ducts in the breast, often leading to inflammation and possible discharge. It is often seen in older women, particularly during menopause. Smoking is considered a risk factor for this condition as it contributes to vascular changes and may affect the ducts. Mondor's disease is a rare condition that involves thrombophlebitis (inflammation of veins caused by blood clots) of the superficial veins in the breast or chest area. Smoking has been linked to vascular changes, which may increase the likelihood of developing Mondor’s disease. Smoking is a well-established risk factor for breast cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Risk factors for breast cancer Modifiable risk factors Non-modifiable risk factors Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29) Age Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK, USA), While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India. Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years Sex Female sex is a risk factor Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer Breastfeeding is a protective factor Ethnicity American white, African-American Parsi in India Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2) Family history of breast cancer 1 first-degree relative RR= 2 2 first-degree relative RR= 3 Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14) Genetic predisposition BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32) Early Menarche(<12years) Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19 Radiation exposure (RR=6) Late Menopause(>55years) Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12 Age at first child <20years - Less risk >35years - High risk High-risk breast lesions Complex fibroadenoma RR=3 Papillomatosis RR=3 Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5 Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10 Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 922,930,931 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 826

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident (RTA) with suspected pelvic fractures. On examination, he is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the earliest treatment for control of haemorrhage in this case?

options.C: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis Explanation: In the case of pelvic fractures with suspected haemorrhage and hypovolemic shock, pelvic compression is a critical step to control bleeding and stabilise the patient. Using bedsheets (or a pelvic binder) to compress the pelvis helps reduce the volume of the pelvic cavity, which in turn minimises bleeding from the fractured vessels and improves hemodynamic stability. Management of Pelvic fractures: The primary goal in managing pelvic fractures with bleeding is to stop the bleeding, as these injuries pose a significant threat to circulation. Initial management: The first step is applying a compression binder or sheet around the true pelvis at the level of the greater trochanters to reduce pelvic volume. This life-saving procedure should be performed in the emergency department immediately. Bleeding sources: Venous Bleeding (85% of cases): Most bleeding originates from veins, which can be controlled non-operatively using pelvic compression (via binding or external fixators). Another technique is extraperitoneal pelvic packing, where the space between the bony pelvis and the peritoneum is packed to compress veins. Arterial Bleeding: If bleeding is arterial in origin, angiographic embolisation becomes the next choice for controlling haemorrhage. Techniques such as compression, packing, fixation, and angiography may be used together, as they can complement one another. If bleeding persists after packing, angiography or other interventions may be necessary. If the source of bleeding is unclear, or if diagnostic imaging (FAST/CT) shows significant blood in the peritoneal cavity, an exploratory laparotomy is warranted to rule out or address concurrent intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.question: A soldier arrives at a referral hospital 24 hours after experiencing a shrapnel injury to his right thigh caused by a high-speed projectile. He expresses significant discomfort at the site of the wound. Upon examination, there is evidence of crepitus. Which of the following microorganisms is the probable culprit behind his current state?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Clostridium perfringens Explanation: The soldier's shrapnel injury to his right thigh, accompanied by significant discomfort, crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues), suggests Gas Gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries. Cause Clostridium perfringens (Option D) Incubation period <24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks Sources and predisposing factors Contaminated soil and feces. Wounds with necrotic or foreign material. Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations. Anaerobic environments in the wound. Common sites of infection Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks. Subscapular region in the upper limb. Clinical features Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity. Serosanguineous discharge. Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae. Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues). Complication Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure. Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections. Death occurs in critically ill patients. Investigation X-ray: Gas in soft tissues. Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils. Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure. Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis. CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds. Treatment High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously. Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously. All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds. Amputation done in severe cases Hyperbaric oxygen therapy. Prevention Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds. Devitalized wounds should not be sutured. Adequate cleaning of wounds with H I O I and normal saline. Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic. Image Clostridium septicum (Option A) causes spontaneous, non-traumatic gas gangrene and is associated with conditions like colorectal cancer or immunocompromised states, whereas Clostridium perfringens is more commonly linked to gas gangrene in traumatic injuries. Clostridioides difficile (Option B) is primarily linked to antibiotic-associated diarrhea and colitis, not gas gangrene, and does not produce the gas or tissue necrosis seen in traumatic injuries. Clostridium novyi (Option C) is a less common cause of gas gangrene, typically associated with specific conditions like soil or animal-related injuries, and is unlikely to be the cause of a shrapnel wound.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Copious sero-sanguinous discharge Explanation: The surest sign of Wound Dehiscence following emergency laparotomy is copious serosanguinous discharge, typically occurring around day 6 post-op, indicating a burst abdomen and requiring urgent laparotomy management. Definition Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound. Occurrence Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days. Types Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera). Risk Factors General: Malnourishment Diabetes Obesity Renal failure Jaundice Sepsis Cancer Treatment with steroids Emergency surgery Local: Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension Poor local wound healing Increased intra-abdominal pressure Clinical Presentation Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), (Option A) Possible evisceration, Popping sensation during straining or coughing. Treatment Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised. Complete dehiscence with evisceration: Requires urgent reoperation. Tension suturing is done. Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury. Antibiotic therapy; fluid management. Rebound tenderness (Option B) refers to pain that is felt when pressure is released from the abdomen, often indicating peritoneal irritation or inflammation, typically seen in conditions like peritonitis. While rebound tenderness could suggest a complication (such as ongoing infection or intra-abdominal issues), it is not specific to wound dehiscence. Hemorrhage (Option C) : Although significant bleeding can occur after surgery, hemorrhage is not a typical feature of wound dehiscence. Hemorrhage can be caused by vessel injury, clotting issues, or inadequate hemostasis at the surgical site, but it's not directly linked to the reopening of the wound itself. Hypotension (Option D) may occur due to various factors like shock, blood loss, or infection. While hypotension can be a result of complications following surgery, it is a general sign of systemic distress rather than a specific sign of wound dehiscence. The cause of hypotension needs to be identified through further clinical investigation.

questions.question: What should be the next course of action in the management of a 30-year-old breastfeeding mother who is experiencing pain and fever in her left breast? The left breast appears abnormal as depicted in the provided image. There is slight swelling of the lymph nodes in the armpit on the affected side, while the opposite breast appears normal. Despite multiple attempts at draining the fluid with the use of antibiotics, it was unsuccessful. An ultrasound examination revealed the presence of fluid collection.
questions.explanation: developed a breast abscess. Breast abscesses are typically caused by bacterial infection and are more common in lactating women due to the increased risk of bacterial colonization of the breast ducts. The presence of fever, pain, and fluid collection seen on ultrasound are also consistent with a breast abscess. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover have been unsuccessful, suggesting that the abscess is not resolving with conservative management alone. Therefore, the next best step in the management of this patient would be incision and drainage of the abscess . Incision and drainage is the most effective way to treat a breast abscess, as it allows for the complete removal of the infected material and helps to prevent recurrence. Incorrect Choices: Option b: Broad-spectrum antibiotics may be used in conjunction with incision and drainage to treat the infection, but antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of a breast abscess. Option c: Breast conservation surgery typically involves the removal of a breast lump or tumor. Thus, breast conservation surgery is not appropriate

questions.question: A barber aged 42 years presented with a healed ulcer as below, over the lower medial aspect of the right leg. On examination, he has varicose veins on both his legs. What is the most likely type of ulcer he had?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Venous ulcer Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is venous ulcer , given the ulcer's location on the medial aspect of the leg and the presence of varicose veins , which are indicative of venous insufficiency. These ulcers commonly occur in areas of chronic venous insufficiency , often associated with varicose veins . Venous ulcer (Option C) Arterial ulcer (Option B) Neuropathic ulcer (Option A) Pressure ulcer Site Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf) At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs. Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc Appearance Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia. Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer. Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here. Punched out ulcer with bone as a base. Cause Caused by

questions.question: False regarding deep second-degree burns:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Painless Explanation: Deep second-degree burns are typically painful . This type of burn damages the epidermis (top layer of skin) and the dermis (tissue below the skin) & It's also known as a deep partial-thickness burn. Deep Partial-Thickness Burns Affected Area Epidermis and reticular dermis (bottom layer of dermis) (Option C ruled out). Clinical Features Painful Loss of epidermis Less moist dermis Fixed capillary staining Reduced sensation No blanching with pressure (Option B ruled out) Healing Takes 3+ weeks : often leads to scarring (Option A ruled out) Treatment May require surgical intervention (e.g., skin grafting) Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 669, 670

questions.question: What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Carbuncle Explanation: The carbuncle is the most likely diagnosis in this case due to the pus-filled masses with necrotic tissue and a yellow centre seen in the image, which is characteristic of this type of deep skin infection. These are composed of two or more furuncles. They classically have multiple pustules, or "heads," originating from the underlying abscess. Carbuncle Definition Infection of hair follicles extending into surrounding and subcutaneous tissue. Cause Staphylococcus aureus. Common Sites Nape of neck, back. Symptoms Red, painful nodule; tender, fluctuant lesion; multiple draining sinuses; fever, lymphadenopathy. Complications Septicemia, abscess, necrosis, requiring possible excision or skin graft. Treatment Control of diabetes; antibiotics; drainage, debridement, possible excision. Botryomycosis (Option A) is a chronic bacterial infection, commonly affecting the skin and rarely the soft tissues, often mistaken for an abscess. It is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, or other bacteria, but it presents more as granulomatous lesions rather than the typical pus-filled carbuncle . Erysipelas (Option B) is a localised cutaneous sharply demarcated infection to the upper layers of the dermis, usually associated with broken skin. It is caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes. It appears to be a red, swollen, and shiny rash , not a deep abscess with pus or necrotic tissue. Ecthyma (Option C) is a deeper form of impetigo caused by bacteria (usually Streptococcus ), which presents as ulcerative lesions with a crusted appearance , not as a deep abscess with dead tissue and a yellow centre.

questions.question: What is the ideal pressure setting for vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy?
questions.explanation: setting for VAC therapy. It is considered ideal for promoting wound healing, reducing edema, and enhancing blood flow while minimizing tissue damage. Most clinical guidelines and studies support this pressure as the optimal setting for standard VAC therapy. Incorrect Options: Option B - 60 to 80 mm Hg: This lower pressure range may be used in specific situations, such as when treating wounds over sensitive or delicate areas where higher pressures might cause discomfort or tissue damage. However, it is generally not considered the ideal setting for most VAC applications. Option C - 130 mm Hg : Although close to the recommended pressure, this slightly higher setting may increase the risk of tissue damage and discomfort, making it less ideal compared to the 125 mm Hg setting. Option D - 80 to 100 mm Hg: This range may be used for certain wounds where a lower pressure is needed, such as in patients with compromised circulation or delicate tissues. However, it is not the standard pressure setting for VAC therapy in most cases.

questions.question: An 84-year-old man who had a stroke 2 years ago and has been on extended bed rest, develops a pressure ulcer with partial skin thickness loss and a clean base. What is the grade of his pressure sore?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2 Explanation: The pressure ulcer described in the scenario has partial skin thickness loss with a clean base , characteristic of a Grade 2 pressure sore. Pressure sore stages Stage I (Option A ruled out) Early superficial ulcer Non blanchable erythema of the skin, without breach in the epidermis Stage II (Option B) Late superficial ulcer Partial thickness, less including epidermis + dermis Stage III (Option C ruled out) Early deep ulcer Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissues but not through underlying fascia Stage IV (Option D ruled out) Late deep ulcer Full-thickness skin loss involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle, bone, joints or tendon. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 22, 23

questions.question: A 35-year-old male had surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to significant contamination, only the sheath was sutured, leaving the wound open. Daily wound irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What type of wound-healing mechanism is occurring in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tertiary intention Explanation: The type of wound healing mechanism described in this scenario is tertiary intention (also known as ( delayed primary closure ). Wound healing Healing by primary intention (Option A ruled out) It occurs when the edges of a clean wound are brought together and secured with sutures, staples, or adhesives. Minimal scarring occurs. Healing by secondary intention (Option B ruled out) The wound is left open to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialisation. This is common in wounds with significant tissue loss or contamination. Healing by tertiary intention (delayed primary closure) (Option C) The wound is initially left open and then closed surgically after several days when it's clean and granulating. This is used for contaminated wounds to prevent infection. Quaternary intention (Option D) is not a recognised term in wound healing. The proper classification includes primary, secondary, and tertiary intention.

questions.question: A friend of yours is teaching you about enhanced recovery after surgery. Which of the following statements he makes is inaccurate? A. III Prolonged fasting is necessary

options.B: Epidural anaesthesia recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control
options.C: Reduction of hospital stay by 2-3 weeks
options.D: Beta-blockers are given after major surgery done under general anaesthesia to improve the outcome

questions.explanation: III Prolonged fasting is necessary Correct Answer: A) III Prolonged fasting is necessary Explanation: ERAS protocols emphasise reducing fasting times before surgery. It allows a light meal up to six hours before surgery and clear fluids up to two hours prior. It also includes carbohydrate-rich drinks up to two hours before the procedure as it helps reduce postoperative insulin resistance, preserve muscle mass, minimize protein loss, and alleviate preoperative thirst, hunger, and anxiety. ERAS is a set of evidence-based guidelines aimed at improving recovery after surgery. It focuses on optimising preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative care to speed up recovery, reduce complications, and shorten hospital stays. Epidural anaesthesia recommended in laparoscopic surgery for pain control (Option B) is true because it is one of the main component of ERAS and it can be used for effective pain control in many types of surgery, including laparoscopic surgery. However, its use may depend on the type of surgery and the patient’s condition. Reduction of hospital stay by 2-3 weeks (Option C) is correct as one of the key goals of ERAS is to reduce the length of hospital stay. Beta-blockers are given after major surgery done under general anaesthesia to improve outcome (Option D) is true and is mainly given to improve cardiovascular outcome. Reference: Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 10. AANA Link .

questions.question: During laparoscopic surgery, where shouldn't the trocar be inserted?
questions.explanation: during laparoscopic surgery requires careful consideration to avoid injury to major blood vessels, including both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries . Inferior epigastric artery (IEA): Located on the posterior aspect of the rectus sheath, arising from the external iliac artery , it is at risk when inserting trocars in the lower abdominal wall. Superior epigastric artery (SEA): A continuation of the internal thoracic artery , it supplies the upper abdominal wall and is at risk in upper trocar insertions . Both arteries run within the rectus sheath , making them relevant in trocar placement at different levels of the anterior abdominal wall. Trocar Placement & Epigastric Arteries: Trocar Site At Risk Artery Precautions Umbilical (Primary) Minimal risk Insert at linea alba Supraumbilical (Upper Trocar) Superior Epigastric Artery Avoid midline rectus sheath Infraumbilical/Midclavicular Inferior Epigastric Artery Insert lateral to rectus muscle Palmar’s Point (LUQ Trocar) Minimal risk Used in difficult access cases Superior Epigastric Artery (Option A): Incorrect alone because it is only at risk in upper abdominal trocar placement . Inferior Epigastric Artery (Option B): Incorrect alone because both superior and inferior epigastric arteries are at risk depending on trocar position . Abdominal Aorta (Option C): Incorrect because the aorta is a deep retroperitoneal structure, not directly relevant to trocar insertion . Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, Ed 28, Pg 102, 103 SRB’s Surgical Operations, Text and Atlas, Edition 1, Pg. 550,551 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4664217/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5206834/

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident.O/E, he had multiple injuries all over his body and was found to be in class III hemorrhagic shock. The percentage of blood loss would be between:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 30-40% Explanation: The percentage of blood loss in class III hemorrhagic shock is 30-40%. Generalized vasoconstriction. Decompensated shock. Refractory shock. Heart Rate <100/min 100-120/min 120-140/min >140/min Blood Pressure Normal Hypotension Marked hypotension Profound hypotension Respiratory Rate Normal Tachypnea Tachypnea Tachypnea Urine Output >30 ml/hour 20-30 ml/hour 5-15 ml/hour No urine output Mental Status Alert, normal Anxious, mildly agitated Confused, altered mental status Comatose, lethargic Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 105, 106, 107 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 13, 14

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is found unconscious after a fall from a ladder. In the emergency department, his eyes do not open even in response to pain; he is making incomprehensible sounds, and he exhibits abnormal flexion in response to painful stimuli. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B)6 Explanation: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a tool used to assess a patient’s level of consciousness based on three parameters: eye-opening , verbal response , and motor response . Each parameter is scored, and the total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake). Eye response : The patient's eyes do not open, even in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 1 . Verbal response : The patient makes incomprehensible sounds, corresponding to a score of 2 . Motor response : The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing) in response to pain, corresponding to a score of 3 . Thus, the GCS score for this patient is: 1 (Eye) + 2 (Verbal) + 3 (Motor) = 6 Simplified Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) Table Category Response Score Eye Opening (E) Spontaneous 4 To speech 3 To pain 2 None 1 Verbal Response (V) Oriented 5 Confused conversation 4 Inappropriate words 3 Incomprehensible sounds 2 None 1 Motor Response (M) Obeys commands 6 Localizes to pain 5 Withdraws from pain 4 Abnormal flexion (decorticate) 3 Abnormal extension (decerebrate) 2 No response 1 Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification Minor head injury GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness) Mild head injury GCS 14 or 15 with LOC Moderate head injury GCS 9 - 13 Severe head injury GCS 3 - 8 The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS. Pupils Unreactive to Light Pupil Reactivity Score Both Pupils 2 One Pupil 1 Neither Pupil 0 GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15 GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 357, 361 https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/what-is-gcs-p/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513298/

questions.question: A 20-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a swelling on his wrist. He reports fluctuation in size , mild numbness in the hand , and occasional pain . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ganglion cyst , which is the most common soft tissue swelling of the wrist. Supporting features: Location : Commonly over the dorsal aspect of the wrist (as seen in image) Fluctuation in size : Classic feature due to cyst fluid dynamics Mild numbness : Can occur if the cyst compresses nearby nerves Occasional pain : Especially with wrist movement or pressure Differentiating Wrist Masses: Condition Characteristics Pain Fluctuation in Size Numbness Lipoma Soft, mobile, subcutaneous fat mass No No No Ganglion cyst Fluid-filled, over joint or tendon sheath, translucent Occasional Yes Rare Dermoid cyst Congenital, contains ectodermal elements (hair/sebum) Rare Rare Yes Hematoma Post-trauma, discoloured, self-resolving Yes (initially) No No Lipoma (Option A): Typically soft, non-fluctuant, and slow-growing; not commonly associated with wrist joints or changes in size with activity. Dermoid cyst (Option C): Usually congenital, midline, and more common in children; contains ectodermal elements, and rarely found over the wrist joint. Hematoma (Option D): Usually follows trauma, appears bruised or discoloured, and resolves over time; not fluctuant or recurrent like this. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470168/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK507906/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6258973/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/5484

questions.question: A woman, a few weeks after delivery, complains of bloody discharge from nipple and fever. On examination, diffuse lump under areola. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: → Lactating women are at high risk of mastitis due to milk stasis and bacterial infection. Bloody nipple discharge and fever → Suggests infection and inflammation , which are characteristic of lactational mastitis . Diffuse lump under the areola → Likely represents engorgement or inflammatory induration due to stasis or bacterial invasion (commonly Staphylococcus aureus ). Lactational Mastitis Feature Lactational Mastitis Etiology Bacterial infection due to milk stasis (commonly Staphylococcus aureus ) Risk Factors Breastfeeding, nipple trauma (cracks), poor latch, prolonged engorgement Symptoms Fever, malaise, painful swollen breast , erythema, bloody or purulent discharge Examination Tender indurated mass , warmth, erythema over the affected breast Complications Breast abscess (if untreated) Management Frequent breastfeeding, warm compress, analgesics, antibiotics (dicloxacillin, cephalexin) Galactocele (Option A): Incorrect because it presents as a painless cystic swelling due to milk retention , without fever, tenderness, or bloody discharge . Mondor disease (Option C): Incorrect because it is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast , presenting as a palpable cord-like structure , not a diffuse lump or fever . Fibrocystic disease (Option D): Incorrect because it causes cyclic breast pain and nodularity, typically worsening before menstruation, not postpartum infection . Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. Pg 1040

questions.question: A patient with dilated tortuous veins of the leg presented to the OPD and is diagnosed with varicose vein of grade C4a. What is the best preferred treatment?
questions.explanation: classification) indicate skin changes such as pigmentation or eczema due to chronic venous insufficiency. Endothermal ablation (radiofrequency or laser) is the first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. It is minimally invasive, effective, and has faster recovery compared to open surgery . CEAP Classification & Treatment of Varicose Veins CEAP Class Clinical Features Preferred Treatment C0 No visible/palpable signs No treatment needed C1 Telangiectasias or reticular veins Conservative (compression) C2 Varicose veins Compression, ablation, or surgery C3 Edema Endothermal ablation C4a Pigmentation/eczema Endothermal ablation C4b Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche Endothermal or open surgery C5 Healed venous ulcer Endothermal ablation + ulcer care C6 Active venous ulcer Multimodal therapy Compression (Option A): Incorrect because while compression stockings help relieve symptoms, they do not treat the underlying venous reflux . Non-endothermal non-tumescent ablation (Option C): Incorrect because options like cyanoacrylate glue or mechanochemical ablation are alternative treatments but not first-line . Open surgery (Option D): Incorrect because surgical vein stripping is now reserved for cases where endothermal ablation is not feasible . Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1814 Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1030 CEAP

questions.question: The ureter is safe in which type of hysterectomy?
questions.explanation: because: The procedure is performed entirely through the vaginal route without significant dissection near the ureter. There is less manipulation of pelvic structures compared to other approaches. Other methods like open, laparoscopic, and robotic hysterectomy involve greater ureteric handling, increasing the risk of thermal injury, ligation, or transection . Ureteric Safety in Hysterectomy Types Hysterectomy Type Ureteric Injury Risk Reasons Open laparotomy Moderate Direct ureteric handling, risk during ligation Laparoscopic High Increased risk due to thermal and traction injuries Robotic Moderate to high Similar to laparoscopic but better visualization Vaginal Lowest Minimal ureteric dissection, lower risk of injury Open laparotomy (Option A): Incorrect because ureteric injury can occur during ligation of uterine vessels or parametrial dissection . Laparoscopy (Option B): Incorrect as ureteric injury is common due to thermal damage from electrocautery . Robotic (Option C): Incorrect since it has a similar risk as laparoscopic hysterectomy . Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5385136/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7363243/

questions.question: Identify the grade of the condition given in the image below ?
questions.explanation: characteristic of a Grade 4 pressure sore, the most severe level of pressure-induced tissue damage. Incorrect Options: Option A - Grade 1: This is the earliest stage of a pressure sore where damage is limited to superficial layers of the skin. Option B - Grade 2: This stage involves damage beyond the epidermis into the dermis, often resembling an abrasion, blister, or shallow crater. Option C - Grade 3: The ulcer has extended deeper into the tissue but has not yet reached the muscle or bone.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male with a history of a road traffic accident presents to the emergency department. His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On examination, breath sounds are absent on the right side. What is the next step in management? D. III Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head

options.A: Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway
options.B: Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line
options.C: Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Secure airway, give oxygen, insert ICD, secure IV line Explanation: The patient has GCS 8/15 , indicating a severe head injury and possible impaired consciousness . Therefore, securing the airway is the priority to prevent further deterioration. Oxygen should be administered to address the low oxygen saturation (85%). The absence of breath sounds on the right side raises concern for tension pneumothorax or large pneumothorax , which can lead to respiratory failure . In this case, the next step is to insert an intercostal chest drain (ICD) to relieve any pneumothorax and re-expand the lung. IV access should be secured for fluid resuscitation or medication administration, but airway and breathing take precedence. We will follow a primary survey of A, B, C, D, and E to manage this patient, where A is securing the airway, B is giving oxygen and inserting ICD, and C includes IV line. Start IV fluids, give atropine and secure airway (Option A) : Securing the airway is important, but giving atropine is not the priority here because the patient has a heart rate of 60 bpm , which is not significantly low and does not require atropine at this stage. Evaluate for head injury and do CT-head (Option C) : The immediate concern is the airway and respiratory distress . The absence of breath sounds on the right side suggests a life-threatening thoracic injury that should be managed first, with a CT scan of the head being considered later once the patient is stabilised. Administer IV dextrose followed by NCCT head (Option D) : There is no indication that the patient is hypoglycemic or in need of IV dextrose at this moment. The priority should be stabilising the airway and managing the potential pneumothorax . The NCCT head can be done later if head injury is suspected after stabilizing the patient. Reference: Sabiston, Text Book of Surgery, 21st edition, Pages 391, 392

questions.question: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. An ultrasound (USG) shows distention of the portal vein, and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been administered. What is the next appropriate step in management?

options.A: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
options.B: Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
options.C: Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
options.D: Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.explanation: presenting with severe hematemesis, which suggests significant blood loss. The immediate priority is stabilizing the patient by administering intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, replace lost fluids, and correct electrolyte imbalances. Incorrect Options: Option A - Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics: While antibiotics may be needed later in managing a patient with suspected variceal bleeding and cirrhosis (to prevent infections like spontaneous bacterial peritonitis), it is not the immediate next step. The priority is to stabilize the patient first. Option B - Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis: A liver biopsy is useful for diagnosing the extent of liver fibrosis or cirrhosis. However, in the acute setting of severe hematemesis, it is inappropriate as the immediate next step. The patient needs urgent stabilization, not an invasive diagnostic procedure. Option D - Perform an endoscopy to look for varices: Endoscopy is essential for diagnosing and managing variceal bleeding, particularly in a patient with portal hypertension secondary to chronic alcohol use. However, it should be performed after initial stabilization, including fluid resuscitation and hemodynamic support. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following is a complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a sepsis patient in the ICU?
questions.explanation: ill patients, such as those with sepsis (metabolic disorders). The high glucose content of TPN, combined with insulin resistance often seen in sepsis, can lead to significant elevations in blood glucose levels. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hyperlipidemia: TPN can sometimes lead to elevated lipid levels, especially if the lipid component is administered in excess. However, this is less common in the acute setting of a septic patient compared to hyperglycemia. Option C - Hyperglyceridemia: While TPN contains lipids that can elevate glyceride levels, hyperglyceridemia is not as common or clinically significant as hyperglycemia in the acute management of sepsis. Option D - Hypoglycemia: Although hypoglycemia can occur if TPN is suddenly stopped or if there is an insulin overdose, it is not a common complication during the administration of TPN, especially in a septic patient where hyperglycemia is more likely.

questions.question: Which of the following is characteristic of hypovolemic shock?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) High vascular resistance Explanation: In Hypovolemic shock, as the body tries to compensate for the reduced blood volume, the blood vessels constrict (vasoconstriction) to preserve blood pressure and redirect blood flow to vital organs like the heart and brain. This results in increased vascular resistance. Decreased cardiac output (Option A) : Since there's less blood to pump, the heart cannot maintain a normal cardiac output. This is opposite to what happens in some other types of shock (e.g., septic shock), where cardiac output may initially increase. Decreased venous pressure (Option C) : Lower blood volume means less blood returning to the heart, leading to reduced venous pressure. Decreased mixed venous saturation (Option D) : In hypovolemic shock, oxygen delivery is impaired, and the blood returning to the heart has a lower oxygen saturation, which is reflected in a lower mixed venous oxygen saturation. Physiological Hemodynamic Characteristics of Shock Type of Shock Cardiac Output Systemic Vascular Resistance Central Venous Pressure Mean Arterial Pressure Hypovolemic ↓ ↑ ↓ ↓ Cardiogenic ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓ Distributive(Septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic) ↑ or ↓ ↓ ↓ or N ↓ Obstructive (pulmonary embolism, cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax) ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓ Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 12

questions.question: Identify the type of ulcer shown in the image below:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Trophic ulcer Explanation: Trophic ulcers, also referred to as neuropathic ulcers occur due to a loss of sensation and an impaired ability to protect the skin, often resulting from conditions like peripheral neuropathy or poor circulation. These ulcers are usually present with well-defined borders and a pale or pink wound bed, commonly located in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction is frequent. Type of Ulcer: Type History Lesion Characteristics Pain Ischemic/Arterial Smoking, intermittent claudication Irregular edges, poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency Venous Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate Mild; relieved by elevation Neurotrophic Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone None Malignant Ulcer History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma) Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumor with hard, indurated tissue Often painful, can be associated with bleeding or foul odor

questions.question: A 30-year-old female who is receiving cyclosporine A following renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of the treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fibroadenoma Explanation: The biopsy image shows a proliferation of ducts arranged in both intracanalicular and pericanalicular patterns, surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma, suggesting Fibroadenoma. These tumours are common in young women, and hormonal changes may influence their growth. Cyclosporine A, which has hormonal effects, could contribute to the development of fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma: It is the most common benign breast tumour, typically found in women aged 15-35. Characteristics: Spherical masses measuring 1-10 cm, firm, non-tender, well-circumscribed, mobile and often single . The lump is mobile and slippery and hence called breast mouse. Estrogen sensitivity: Can increase in size during pregnancy, lactation, or estrogen therapy and usually regress after menopause. HPE: Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule , with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components. Popcorn calcification on mammogram. Ageing effect: Epithelium atrophies with age, and the stroma becomes more hyalinised. questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a swelling in the back of his neck that has been present for almost a year. The swelling has not increased in size. On examination, it is non-pulsatile, and the slip sign is positive, with the swelling measuring 3x3 cm. Which of the following statements is most likely true?

options.D: Excision can be done if the patient requests it

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Excision can be done if the patient requests it Explanation: Based on the clinical features (non-pulsatile, stable size, and positive slip sign), this is most likely a lipoma , which is a benign tumour of fatty tissue. If the patient requests excision, and if there are no concerns about malignancy, excision can be performed to remove the lipoma for cosmetic or symptomatic reasons. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumour composed of mature adipocytes (fat cells) and is the most common soft tissue tumor. These tumors are generally soft, mobile, and painless masses found beneath the skin. Most frequently found on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and arms. questions.question: A 47-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He has a history of electric burns to the scalp 8 years ago. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

options.B: It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
options.D: Long-duration antibiotics will improve the condition.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma Explanation: Chronic non-healing ulcers , especially those resulting from burn injuries or other trauma, are at high risk of malignant transformation , most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) . This is known as Marjolin's ulcer , which can develop in areas of chronic injury or scar tissue. questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe pain and swelling in her right hand, which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury in the garden 5 days ago. On examination, she cries out in pain when her hand is extended and when the palmar aspect is palpated passively. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

options.A: More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand
options.B: X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients
options.D: Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It requires incision and drainage Explanation: The patient likely has a deep palmar abscess secondary to a foreign body, and incision and drainage (I&D) is required to relieve pressure, remove the foreign body, and treat the infection. Deep Palmar Infection: These infections begin in the palm and may be confined to a web space initially. As the infection progresses, the entire hand becomes swollen and tender due to the accumulation of pus on either side of the septum. Management: The treatment involves incision and drainage (I&D) with a thorough washout of the wound. It's essential to open all affected deep spaces. In some cases, incisions may be needed on both the dorsal and volar sides of the hand. If the extent of the infection is unclear, imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI can be used to delineate the spread within the deep palmar spaces. Incorrect Options: More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand (Option A) : Infections or abscesses caused by foreign bodies are more common in the palmar aspect due to the tighter fascial compartments. X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients (Option B) : X-rays are not always helpful, especially for non-radio-opaque foreign bodies (wood), so other imaging like ultrasound might be more useful. questions.question: A patient fell from a train onto the railway track and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital, and the following procedure was performed (image shown below). What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Life-saving procedure Explanation: In cases of severe trauma , such as being run over or falling on railway tracks, injuries can be so extensive that amputation is necessary to prevent massive blood loss , gangrene , or infection , which can lead to death. The decision for a bilateral below-knee amputation is usually made as a life-saving measure when there is irreversible damage to the legs. Indications for Amputation: Dead Limb: Gangrene Deadly Limb Wet gangrene Spreading cellulitis Arteriovenous fistula Malignancy (e.g., sarcoma) Dead loss of limb: Severe rest pain due to irreversible critical leg ischemia Paralysis Severe contracture Trauma (irreparable damage) Local Amputation : For small-vessel disease (e.g., diabetes) : Gangrene of toes may require local amputation. If the metatarsophalangeal joint is involved, ray excision may be necessary. Major Amputation: Below-knee Amputation : Preserves knee joint, offering better prosthetic use. Above-knee Amputation : For poor circulation or non-mobilizing patients. Knee Disarticulation : Preserves femur and patella for better prosthetic function. Post-operative care: Pain Management : Regular opiate use. Limb Care : Prevent pressure ulcers on the remaining limb. Exercise : Prevent deformities, build strength, and improve mobility. Complications: Early : Hemorrhage, infection, gas gangrene, and wound dehiscence. Late : Phantom limb pain, stump ulceration, DVT, and pulmonary embolism Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1014,1015

questions.question: In solid organ transplantation, which of the following organs is associated with a higher incidence of rejection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lungs Explanation: Survival after lung transplantation continues to improve over time; however, the rates remain lower compared to other solid organ transplants. Around 50% of lung transplant recipients will face at least one episode of acute rejection within the first year . Furthermore, by five years post-transplant , roughly half of recipients will have developed chronic rejection . Incorrect Options: Kidney transplantation: (Option C) Graft rejection rate for kidney transplants is quite low after the first year. Specifically, with living-donor kidneys , the 1-year survival rate is 98% , and with deceased-donor kidneys , the 1-year survival rate is 93% . At 5 years, the graft survival rate for living-donor kidneys is 85%, and for deceased-donor kidneys, it is 75% . By 10 years, the survival rates drop to 65% for living-donor kidneys and 48% for deceased-donor kidneys, indicating a gradual decline due to chronic processes rather than acute rejection episodes. Liver transplantation (Option D): Chronic rejection occurs in about 13-17% of recipients Intestinal transplantation (Option B): Chronic rejection occurs in about 10% of recipients.
